column3: Cold Chain Management
column4: PREVENTION SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Real-time monitoring of trucks, warehouses, and shipping containers could reduce waiting times and errors through RFID/sensors.
column41: Lower sensor costs to less than $10 per pallet and improve effectiveness to meet needs of logistics providers.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Inventory Management
column4: PREVENTION SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Half of the market does not utilize advanced inventory management systems today.
column41: Target small- and medium-size customers through development of low-cost, flexible solutions.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Packaging Adjustments
column4: PREVENTION SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Consumers haven’t demanded adjustments, and modifications raise concerns about unintended consequences such as breakage.
column41: Conduct consumer behavior research to identify core needs. Fund product R&D to pilot disruptive packaging such as edible films or nonstick bottles.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Spoilage Prevention Packaging
column4: PREVENTION SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Applicability is limited to certain food types and types of storage.
column41: Improve performance across a wider variety of food types and storage settings.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Waste Tracking & Analytics
column4: PREVENTION SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Market penetration of solutions is small to date.
column41: Minimize manual measurement through lowcost cameras and sensors and integration with inventory data.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Dynamic Store Merchandising
column40: System costs are tremendous, relying on real-time price screens, strong inventory management systems, smart carts, and handheld devices.
column41: Verify NPV through a retail pilot, and identify path to reduce costs. Experiment with locationbased mobile phone discounting to reduce total solution cost.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Smart Labeling
column40: The NPV of this solution has not been proven through the limited pilots to date.
column41: Achieve labels that are cheap enough to drive a food-safety or waste-reduction value proposition when placed on the majority of perishables.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Value-Added Processing
column4: RECOVERY SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Facilities are expensive and require large scale, reducing applicability for smaller recovery opportunities.
column41: Develop distributed and mobile technologies, combined with new preservation technologies, to cost-effectively link processing on farms to businesses and recovery organizations
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Donation Transportation, Donation Storage & Handling
column4: RECOVERY SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: New infrastructure can be costly and limited in the amount of time it is actually in use.
column41: Identify novel tools to allow for effortless sharing of existing, under-utilized infrastructure not currently linked to recovery networks.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Centralized AD
column4: RECYCLING SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Additional labor cost is needed to depackage food, reducing the quantity and quality for recycling.
column41: Scale down large depackaging technology to enable systems at every retailer and manufacturer location.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Home Composting
column4: RECYCLING SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Current adoption is low due to poor designs, lack of space, and odors.
column41: Achieve odor-free, beginner-level home composting systems for under $50 per unit.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Centralized Composting
column4: RECYCLING SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Compostable packaging underperforms vs. industry standards and can decrease shelf life of perishables while costing 25% to 100% more.
column41: Conduct R&D in compostable packaging to achieve products on par with conventional price and performance
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Animal Feed
column4: RECYCLING SOLUTIONS BREAKTHROUGHS IN EXISTING SOLUTIONS
column40: Facilities currently rely on individual relationships.
column41: Leverage sharing economy to create a network of waste generators and farms.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Small-Scale AD
column40: Biogas cleaning and electricity conversion is not economical at small business scale, utilization for heat is seasonal,74 and on-site handling of digestate is challenging for small businesses.7
column41: Achieve transformational cost reductions to be commercially viable, which would drive massive collection cost reductions in lowdensity municipalities and rapid scale similar to distributed energy systems.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Collection
column40: Collection costs can make up 50% to 75% of the overall cost for collecting and processing food waste.
column41: Develop new route optimization technology and new tools to reduce water weight of food scraps before or during transit.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Using active intelligent packaging to prolong product freshness and slow down spoilage of perishable fruit and meat

column3: Providing restaurants and prepared-food providers with data on wasteful practices to inform behavior and operational changes

column3: Reducing product loss during shipment to retail distribution centers by using direct shipments and cold-chain-certified carriers

column3: Businesses that purchase unwanted processed food and produce direct from manufacturers/distributors for discounted retail sale to consumers
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Identifying opportunities to reduce food waste from manufacturing/ processing operations and product line changeovers
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Conducting large-scale consumer advocacy campaigns to raise awareness of food waste and educate consumers about ways to save money and reduce wasted food
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Using a technology platform to connect individual food donors with recipient organizations to reach smaller-scale food donations
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Expanding temperature-controlled food distribution infrastructure (e.g. refrigeration, warehouses) and labor availability to handle (e.g. process, package) additional donation volumes
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Providing small-scale transportation infrastructure for local recovery as well as long-haul transport capabilities
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Extending the usable life of donated foods through processing methods such as making soups, sauces, or other value-added products

column3: Educating potential food donors on donation liability laws
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Standardizing local and state health department regulations for safe handling and donation of food through federal policy
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: s Expanding federal tax benefits for food donations to all businesses and simplifying donation reporting for tax deductions

column3: A series of biological processes in which microorganisms break down biodegradable material in the absence of oxygen resulting in two end products: biogas and digestate. There are many different AD technologies, including wet and dry versions, the latter being generally better suited for food waste mixed with yard waste.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column2: Water Resource Recovery Facility (WRRF) with AD
column3: Delivering waste by truck or through existing sink disposal pipes to a municipal WRRF, where it is treated with anaerobic digestion; the biosolids can be applied to land for beneficial reuse
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Composting at small scale at institutions or businesses with heat and mechanical power to compost relatively quickly (less than one month versus more than two months for windrow composting)
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: An on-site treatment technology, greywater aerobic digesters use combinations of nutrients or enzymes and bacteria to break food organics down until soluble, where it is flushed into the sewage system.
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Transporting food from homes by truck, car, or bicycle to small, community, or neighborhood-level compost facilities that process 2,500 tons per year on average
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Transporting waste to a centralized facility where it decomposes into compost
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Feeding food waste to animals after it is heat-treated and dehydrated and either mixed with dry feed or directly fed
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent

column3: Keeping a small bin or pile for on-site waste at residential buildings to be managed locally; also known as “backyard composting”
column43: A Roadmap to Reduce U.S. Food Waste by 20 Percent
